awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: Development of an Integrated Molecular Design Environment for Lubrication Systems (iMoDELS)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on developing, deploying and distributing the Integrated Molecular Design Environment for Lubrication Systems (iMoDELS), an open-source simulation and design environment (SDE) that encapsulates the expertise of specialists in first principles, forcefields and molecular simulation related to nanoscale lubrication in a simple web-based interface.  The iMoDELS SDE is being developed using model-integrated computing (MIC), a state-of-the-art powerful, well-established, extensible, community-supported, and application-hardened software engineering framework that supports scientific and engineering workflows.  Making iMoDELS broadly accessible is motivated by the high cost (over $800B/yr in the US) of friction and wear, which, along with the methodology to overcome them, lubrication, are collectively known as tribology.  Tribology involves molecular mechanisms occurring on a nanometer scale, and hence understanding tribological behavior on this scale is critical to developing new technologies for reducing wear due to friction.  Deployment of iMoDELS will enable non-computational specialists to be able to evaluate, design and optimize nanoscale lubrication systems, such as hard disk drives, NEMS (nanoelectromechanical systems) and MEMS (microelectromechanical systems), and experiments involving rheological measurements via atomic force microscopes (AFMs) and surface force apparatuses (SFAs).

The iMoDELS SDE brings together a unique combination of materials and computer scientists who will combine their skills to abstract the deep human expertise currently required for the development of simulation-based experiments, thus making broadly available easy-to-use tools to an empirically driven area of science and engineering (nanotribology) of rapidly growing technological importance.  iMoDELS includes the creation and open dissemination of forcefield and simulation results databases that will benefit the simulation community worldwide and catalyze broad-based activity in this area.  The proposed research also includes the interdisciplinary training of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers at the interface of tribology, computational materials sciences, and computer science.  The PIs will use the iMoDELS SDE, and results from it, in presentations used in outreach to local area high school and in classes given to undergraduate students.  The iMoDELS SDE will be vigorously promoted through workshops and presentations at national conferences, and via the dedicated website for development and dissemination.

Reactive force fields (RFFs)- which enable relatively large scale (typically 1,000-1,000,000 atoms) and long-time (typically 1-10 nanoseconds) fully dynamical simulations of molecules, materials and interfaces, have seen a significant interest over the last 20 years. RFFs enable molecular dynamics simulations, predicting the stability of materials and assisting in new material development. The ReaxFF reactive force field method is arguably the most transferable current RFF method - this method has been developed for a wide range of elements, covering a large part of the periodic table.

One major disadvantage of ReaxFF - and similar RFF methods, like COMB, AIREBO and MEAM,  is that its development is time-consuming and not straightforward. Furthermore, applying these methods in molecular dynamics simulations typically requires significant preparation - including extensive structure equilibration. In order to facilitate RFF developments we worked together with a team from Vanderbilt University (PI Peter Cummings) on a web-based interface for both force field development and ReaxFF application. The role of my group was to provide non-trivial training sets (set of quantumchemical data used to develop the ReaxFF parameters) and molecular dynamics simulation setups. For this, we targeted tribochemical applications - simulations related to friction-induced chemistry, in particular targeted at hard-drive systems (silica/silicon interfaces with lubricants). To this end, we formulated ReaxFF training sets for silica/water/silicon and ZDOL-lubricants, as well as fluorinated graphene materials - which have attracted significant interest as potential materials for transistors. We performed ReaxFF MD-simulations demonstrating the complexity of the chemical events during silica/water/silicon friction (Figure 1, Figure 2) - in particular with regards to the role of water in enhancing or reducing the friction surface damage.

Furthermore, in collaboration with scientists from Tsinghua University (China) we applied the ReaxFF silica/water description to study the dynamical behavior of asperities (surface roughness) during friction - which directly related to polishing. We also collaborated with a team from Christian-Albrechts University to develop new mathematical algorithms for ReaxFF force field development purposes - introducing genetic algorithm concepts into the force field development.These new algorithmic concepts have sparked a significant interest in the force field development field - with groups from Caltech, the University of Eindhoven (the Netherlands) and the Army Research Lab (US) publishing similar RFF development algorithms.

Modified by: Adri C Van Duin
